    Miscellaneous plots

    spata-v2-plotting-miscellaneous.Rmd

    1. Introduction

    This tutorial covers all plotting functions that can not be assigned to specific plotting families. Description on how to use functions that visualize dea-analysis results and trajectory-analysis results are integrated in the respective tutorial.

    # load packages
library(SPATA2)
library(tidyverse)

human_gbm <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-gbm275.RDS")

    2. Plot cellular states

    See Genes, Gene-sets & Features to learn how to set up your personally defined gene-sets (or states for that matter). plotFourStates() compares the expression of variables mathematically. It calculates the expression levels of four defined gene-sets for every barcode-spot and assign a position to every barcode.

    # e.g. Neftel et al. 2019 suggested a new classification of tumor cells in glioblastoma multiforme

# These gene sets have been manually added to the spata-object via addGeneSetsInteractive()
four_states <- c("Neftel_OPClike", "Neftel_NPClike2", "Neftel_AClike", "Neftel_Mes_Comb")

plotSurfaceComparison(object = human_gbm, 
                      color_by = four_states, 
                      smooth = TRUE, 
                      smooth_span = 0.25,
                      pt_size = 1.5) + 
  legendNone()

    Figure 2.1 Comparison of expression levels by applying maths 

    plotFourStates(object = human_gbm, 
               states = four_states,
               method_gs = "mean",
               # using color here to underline that the mathematical algorithm is valid
               color_by = "Neftel_Mes_Comb", 
               pt_alpha = 0.75,
               pt_size = 1) +
  legendNone()

    Figure 2.1 Comparison of expression levels by applying maths

    3. Scatterplots

    Numeric variables (genes, gene-sets and numeric features) can be visualized in scatterplots via plotScatterplot().

    plotScatterplot(object = human_gbm, 
                variables = c("nCount_Spatial", "nFeature_Spatial"), 
                pt_clr = "black", 
                smooth = TRUE,
                pt_alpha = 0.75)

plotScatterplot(object = human_gbm, 
                variables = c("GAPDH", "MT2A"),
                smooth = TRUE, 
                smooth_method = "lm",
                pt_clr = "black", 
                pt_alpha = 0.75)

    Figure 3.1 Scatterplots of numeric variables

    4. Gene meta data

    In SPATA2 information about the genes is computed via computeGeneMetaData() and stored in the slot @gdata. For quality control purpose you can visualize summarizing statistics with plotGeneMetaData().

    plotGeneMetaData(object = human_gbm, 
                 variables = c("mean", "sd"), 
                 plot_type = "scatter",
                 pt_clr = "black", 
                 pt_alpha = 0.75)

plotGeneMetaData(object = human_gbm,
                 variables = "stw", 
                 plot_type = "histogram")

    Figure 4.1 Visualization of gene meta data
